name: Survey of Great Plays and Playwrights Online Quiz | Literature | 10 Questions

questions.text: Eugene O'Neill wrote "Long Day's Journey Into Night". Which statement is NOT true of the father in this autobiographical play?
questions.correct: He is battling his own drug addiction
options: He is considered to be "cheap" by his sons
He was a financially successful actor
questions.explanation:
He is battling his own drug addiction.

	O'Neill's autobiographical masterpiece was never performed in his lifetime (at his request). Drug addiction was a problem for his mother, not for his father. America's greatest playwright had a tough life.

questions.text: Arthur Miller wrote "All My Sons". Which statement is true of the storyline?
questions.correct: One brother is in love with the other brother's girlfriend
options: One brother is upset by the other's impending marriage to a famous movie star
One brother has had his life devastated by learning of his father's infidelity
One brother is in conflict with the other regarding the sale of their parents' house
questions.explanation:
One brother is in love with the other brother's girlfriend.

	One brother loves the girlfriend of the other brother (who is missing in action and presumed dead). The "infidelity" answer refers to "Death of a Salesman". The "sale of the house" question refers to "The Price". The reference to "marriage to a star" is based on "After the Fall" (loosely suggested by Miller's marriage to Marilyn Monroe - although I've taken liberties in describing the plot). All were written by Miller.

questions.text: William Inge wrote "The Dark at the Top of the Stairs". Which statement is most descriptive of the play?
questions.correct: A family's struggle to make a living during hard times
options: Problems involved in facing the past as one grows old
Dreams of stardom by an actress
Conflict between two men over one woman
questions.explanation:
A family's struggle to make a living during hard times.

	"Stardom" refers to "Bus Stop". The "romantic triangle" plot refers to "Picnic". The "growing old" reference describes "Come Back, Little Sheba". All were written by Inge (who apparently was not the happiest of people. He committed suicide.)

questions.text: Which play by George Bernard Shaw was the basis for the musical "My Fair Lady"?
questions.explanation:
Pygmalion.

	All of the choices were written by Shaw, but "Pygmalion" was the inspiration for the musical.

questions.text: Tennessee Williams wrote "Cat on A Hot Tin Roof". What is the real name of the "cat"?
questions.explanation:
Maggie.

	She refers to herself in the play as "Maggie, the cat". . Blanche and Stella are from "Streetcar Named Desire". Rosalie was Williams' sister. Williams also had a hard life.

questions.text: Which play is NOT by Edward Albee?
questions.correct: Six Characters in Search of an Author
questions.explanation:
Six Characters in Search of an Author.

	All three were critical successes for Albee. "Six" was by Luigi Pirandello.

questions.text: Who wrote "The Playboy of the Western World"?
questions.explanation:
John Millington Synge.

	Synge also wrote "Riders to the Sea". Hellman wrote "The Children's Hour", Anderson wrote "I Never Sang For My Father", and Wilde wrote "The "Importance of Being Earnest".

questions.text: Which play by Henrik Ibsen is said to be a turning point in women's rights?
questions.explanation:
A Doll's House.

	The slamming of the door as Nora walks out is famous. "Anna" was by O'Neill, "Girl" was by Clifford Odets (who also did "Golden Boy"), "Julie" was by August Strindberg (who authored many plays in his lifetime).

questions.text: Which play is NOT by Anton Chekhov?
questions.explanation:
The Good Woman of Szechuan.

	That one is by the equally prolific Bertolt Brecht.

questions.text: Which statement is true of Thornton Wilder's "Our Town"?
questions.correct: It is set in a small town
options: It is set in a large metropolitan area
It is set in the American West
It is set in ancient times
questions.explanation:
It is set in a small town.

	The story takes place in a small town in New England.
